name: Words by Decade 1931-1940 Quiz | Words by Decade | 10 Questions

questions.text: What was "Asdic" whose development was first recorded in 1939?
questions.correct: an echo-sounding device for the detection of submarines
options: a device for detecting incoming aircraft by using radar
the name of the treaty between Germany and Italy
the monetary system of the Axis powers
questions.explanation:
an echo-sounding device for the detection of submarines.

	Asdic is an acronym formed from the rather clumsy Allied Submarine Detection Investigation Committee. In the early part of the war it was supposedly a secret apparatus but in fact both the Germans and the Japanese knew all about it.

questions.correct: an early type of tape recorder
options: someone who hated jazz music
an early form of walkie-talkie
a special form of office intercom
questions.explanation:
an early type of tape recorder.

	The Blattnerphone recorded on magnetic steel tape. It was named after its inventor L.Blattner (1881-1935)

questions.text: From the attack on which city does the term "fifth-column" first come into the language?
options: Cordoba
Barcelona
Seville
questions.explanation:
Madrid.

	The expression was first used by General Mola as he was besieging Madrid with four columns of troops. The fifth column was the band of his supporters that were waiting for the word to attack inside the city. It came to refer to any enemy planted in your country.

questions.text: What extra specific meaning did the term "guinea-pig" come to have during World War II?
questions.correct: a person who was billetted or evacuated to a strange town or village
options: a person who would use small animals for scientific testing
a person who volunteered for a scientific test in a laboratory
a person who would import a large number of rodents from Guinea
questions.explanation:
a person who was billetted or evacuated to a strange town or village.

	The more familiar use to refer to the subject of an experimental procedure stems from earlier in the century, and did not arise at the time specified in the question. Guinea-pigs were commonly used for scientific testing by the 1920s. The exact date when the meaning extended to human subjects for testing is not fixed.  The use of the phrase in reference to wartime evacuees was documented in a number of publications, although the reason why it was applied is not clear. John Ayto in "20th Century Words" quotes an example of the use of the term "guinea-pig" to apply to evacuees in the "Daily Dispatch" of 1939. He also suggests (without proof) that it came from British slang for the billeting allowance of a guinea. Again a guinea was not the actual allowance.

questions.text: Which of the following items of underclothing was NOT first entered into the dictionary during the 1930s?
options: bra
G-string
briefs
questions.explanation:
panties.

	"Panties" first made its appearance in 1908. "Brassiere" existed as early as 1909 but was only clipped to "bra" in 1937. For a while the clipping "bras" survived until "bra" took over. "G-string" had originally been used as a description of a garment worn by Native American women but the striptease idea drove out this old meaning.

questions.text: What sort of town was a "Hooverville"?
options: a town where the main products were agricultural ones
a town fit for the president of the U.S.A.
a town where the main products were electrical ones
questions.explanation:
a temporary shanty town.

	The name does indeed commemorate Herbert Hoover, President of the U.S.A. from 1929-1933. It is a poignant reminder of the years of economic depression. Amongst the "Hoovervilles" that grew up were ones thrown together by the workers involved in the construction of the Hoover Dam. It is a term used more than once by John Steinbeck.

questions.text: From which popular game did the slang term "screwball" meaning an eccentric or irrational person originally derive?
options: American football
ice hockey
soccer
questions.explanation:
baseball.

	Later the noun "screwball" turned also into an adjective giving rise to such expressions as "screwball comedy" for movies such as "Bringing up Baby".

questions.text: Which vivid color was introduced into the language by Italian-born fashion designer Elsa Schiaparelli?
options: passionate purple
emerald green
electric blue
questions.explanation:
shocking pink.

	Some people called it garish but it caught on. Even Dali is said to have dyed an enormous stuffed bear in shocking pink.

questions.text: What would you do if you started to "simonize"?
questions.correct: You would apply a  wax substance in order to polish something.
options: You would would use one of the early dish-washers.
You would diagnose character from someone's doodles.
You would use a high powered chainsaw.
questions.explanation:
You would apply a  wax substance in order to polish something.

	"Simonize" is the brand name of a wax polish designed to be mainly used on cars. It is first recorded by John Ayto in "20th Century Words" as entering the written language in 1934.

questions.text: In the U.S.A. in the 1930s what would you expect to find a "thumber" doing?
questions.correct: He is someone who thumbs a lift, a hitch-hiker.
options: He is someone who passes counterfeit coins and bills.
He is someone who helps get legislation through Congress.
He is a magician who specializes in card tricks.
questions.explanation:
He is someone who thumbs a lift, a hitch-hiker.

	No one knows for sure whether the expressions "thumbs up" and "thumbs down" were ever really used in the gladiators' arenas of ancient Rome. When hitching a lift the raised thumb was usually meant to symbolize agreement or friendliness in order to get people to stop.
